metadata.title: Nonlocal strain gradient nonlinear resonance of bi-directional functionally graded composite micro/nano-beams under periodic soft excitation

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Thin-Walled Structures
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/tws
Full length article
Nonlocal strain gradient nonlinear resonance of bi-directional functionally graded composite micro/nano-beams under periodic soft excitation Saeid Sahmania, Babak Safaeib,* aMechanical Rotating Equipment Department, Niroo Research Institute (NRI), Tehran 14665-517, Iran bMechanical Engineering Department, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084, China
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Microstructures Inhomogeneous materials Nonlinear resonance Functionally graded composites Numerical analysis
A B S T R A C T
With the aid of advanced design techniques, functionally graded materials as promising new materials can be fabricated into various micro/nano-structures to acquire stronger mechanical performance. In this work, the size-dependent nonlinear primary resonance of periodic soft excited micro/nano-beams made of bi-directional functionally graded materials (2D-FGMs) is studied. To accomplish this end, the nonlocal strain gradient theory of elasticity is utilized within the framework of the refined hyperbolic shear deformation beam theory to construct a size-dependent beam model. On the basis of the variational approach using the principle of Hamilton, the non-classical differential equations of motion are achieved. Thereafter, a discretization scheme based numerical solving process via generalized differential quadrature method (GDQM) together with the pseudo-arclength continuation technique, the nonlocal strain gradient frequency response and amplitude response associated with the nonlinear primary resonance of 2D-FGM micro/nano-beams with different boundary conditions are obtained. It is displayed that the nonlocal size dependency makes a reduction in the oscillation amplitudes associated with both of the bifurcation points, but the strain gradient size effect causes to increase them. These patterns are more significant for the second bifurcation point and for the simply supported-simply supported boundary conditions in comparison with the clamped-clamped ones. Also, it is observed that by increasing the value of both of the axial and lateral material property gradient indexes, the peak of the oscillation amplitude and its associated excitation frequency increase.
1. Introduction
Based upon the inception of manufacturing functionally graded composite materials, it is possible to replace the sharp interfaces existed in traditional composites with gradually changing ones. The growing interest in using this type of composite materials has led to several studies about mechanical responses of structures made of various types of functionally graded materials (FGMs). Liu et al. [1] proposed an integrated strategy to fabricate FGMs via additive manufacturing technology for design of porous structures exploiting topology optimization and stereolithography. Bahreinizad et al. [2] reported a numerical analysis on the application of FGMs for reduction of dogboning in bioabsorbable stents. El-Hadad et al. [3] developed an innovative technique of casting for FGM biomaterials for dental implantology using centrifugal casting method. Safaei et al. [4] anticipated the influence of thermal gradient load on the thermos-elastic natural frequencies of FGM nanocomposite plates. Malakooti et al. [5] enhanced durability and structural integrity of nanogenerators and nanosensors
using nanowire based FGM interfaces. Safaei et al. [6] investigated the influence of loading frequency on the dynamic behavior of FGM nanocomposite plates subjected to periodic thermos-mechanical loading conditions. Zuback et al. [7] investigated the performance of piezoelectric energy harvesters which utilize a FGM nanowire interface rather than a discrete film interface.
Several biological and engineering applications of bi-directional functionally graded materials (2D-FGMs) have been proposed in recent years. For example, Shariyat and Jafari [8] analyzed the nonlinear lowvelocity impact of 2D-FGM circular plates subjected to radial preloads. In order to provide structures with synthetic biomaterials, which can resemble the natural biomaterials, Enab [9] investigated the performance improvement of total knee replacement joint with the aid of using 2D-FGM. Shah and Panda [10] studied the influence of bimodulus behavior of adhesive and curing stresses on interface delamination fracture characteristics of tee joints made of 2D-FGMs.
In recent years, with the aid of rapid advancements in materials science and technology, several investigation have been carried out to

predict the size-dependent mechanical behavior of micro/nano-structures made of FGMs. For instance, Ke et al. [11] predicted bending, buckling and free vibrations of FGM annular microplates using the modified couple stress elasticity theory within the framework of the Mindlin plate theory. Zhang et al. [12] proposed a novel size-dependent FGM curved microbeam model based on the strain gradient theory of elasticity. Ke et al. [13] constructed a modified couple stress plate model for axisymmetric postbuckling analysis of FGM annular microplates considering the physical neutral plane. Rahaeifard [14] reported the size-dependent torsion of FGM microbars with the aid of the modified couple stress elasticity theory. Akgoz and Civalek [15] constructed a non-classical sinusoidal plate model based upon the strain gradient theory of elasticity without any shear correction factor. Shojaeian and Tadi Beni [16] investigated the electromechanical buckling behavior of FGM electrostatic nano-bridges on the basis of the modified couple stress theory. Ashoori et al. [17] analyzed the size-dependent nonlinear bending and snap-through phenomenon in FGM piezoelectric plates using modified couple stress theory of elasticity. Canadija et al. [18] extended the Euler-Bernoulli beam formulation using the nonlocal strain gradient theory within the nonhomogenous temperature field setting. Sahmani and Aghdam [19–22] adopted the surface elasticity theory with the classical shell theory to capture surface stress effect on the nonlinear instability of hybrid FGM nanoshells. Thai et al. [23] introduced a robust numerical model to take size effect into mechanical properties of FGM microplates via the modified strain gradient elasticity theory and isogeometric analysis. Maleki et al. [24] examined the size-dependent strain energy rate release rate for FGM Euler-Bernoulli nanobeams modeled via the modified couple stress theory of elasticity. Acierno et al. [25] studied polypropylene fibers containing singlewalled carbon nanotubes in terms of the experimental mechanical properties as well as numerical nonlocal models. Sahmani and Aghdam [26], Sahmani and Fattahi [27,28] studied the effect of surface stress size dependency on the buckling and postbuckling of FGM nanoshells including the geometrical imperfection. Deng et al. [29] employed the nonlocal theory of elasticity for the size-dependent analysis of free vibrations of multi-span viscoelastic FGM nanopipes conveying fluid. Liu et al. [30] investigated the nonlocal vibration and biaxial buckling characteristics of double-viscoelastic-FGM-nanoplate system based on the Eringen's nonlocality and Kelvin model. Fang et al. [31] explored the size-dependent wave propagation in viscoelastic cylindrical nanoshells. Sahmani and Fattahi [32–35] developed nonlocal models with calibrated value of the nonlocal parameter for size-dependent mechanical behavior of nanostructures. Trinh et al. [36] analyzed the sizedependent buckling and free vibration responses of FGM sandwich microplates based upon the modified couple stress theory of elasticity. Yang et al. [37] developed a nonlocal Euler-Bernoulli beam model for nonlinear bending, buckling and vibration behaviors of nanobeams made of 2D-FGM. Sarafraz et al. [38] introduced a surface elastic beam model to analyze the nonlinear secondary resonance of nanobeams under hard excitations.
Through several studies applying the nonlocal theory of elasticity, misleading information because of only accounting for softening mechanical behaviors of nanostructures led to suffer researchers. On the contrary, the strain gradient elasticity theory only takes hardening mechanical responses of small scale structures. As a result, Lim et al. [39] concluded that the nonlocal parameter and strain gradient length scale parameter describe different features of material properties at micro/nano-scale. So, they were motivated to combine the two elasticity theories in a unified theory namely as the nonlocal strain gradient elasticity.
Afterwards, several investigations have been performed in which the nonlocal strain gradient elasticity has put to use to capture size dependency in mechanical responses of micro/nano-structures. For instance, Li and Hu [40] employed the nonlocal strain gradient theory of elasticity to analyze the nonlinear buckling characteristics of EulerBernoulli nanobeams. Additionally, they predicted the nonlocal strain
gradient frequency of wave motion on nanotubes conveying fluid [41]. Yang et al. [42] anticipated the critical nonlocal strain gradient voltages associated with the pull-in instability of functionally graded nano-actuators. Simsek [43] constructed a nonlocal strain gradient beam model for nonlinear vibrations of functionally graded Euler-Bernoulli nanobeams. Farajpour et al. [44] examined buckling behavior of orthotropic nonlocal strain gradient plates using a new size-dependent plate model. Tang et al. [45] analyzed the nonlocal strain gradient wave propagation in a viscoelastic nanotube. With the aid of the strain gradient elasticity theory, Sahmani and Aghdam [46–49] studied the linear and nonlinear vibrations of supramolecular lipid micro/nano-tubules within the both prebuckling and postbuckling domains. Li et al. [50] anticipated the size-dependent bending, buckling and free vibration characteristics of axially functionally graded nonlocal strain gradient beams. Radwan and Sobhy [51] explored the influences of nonlocality and strain gradient size dependency on the dynamic deformation of orthotropic viscoelastic graphene sheets subjected to a time harmonic thermal loading condition. Sahmani and Aghdam [52–54] reported analytical expressions for the nonlocal strain gradient nonlinear buckling and postbuckling behavior of hydrostatic pressurized multilayer FGM nanoshells. Lu et al. [55] proposed a unified size-dependent beam model including various higher-order shear deformation beam theories to analyze the simultaneous effects of nonlocal stress and strain gradient. Apuzzo et al. [56] predicted the size-dependent axial and flexural free vibrations of Bernoulli-Euler nanobeams on the basis of the modified nonlocal strain gradient model of elasticity. Sahmani et al. [57] used the nonlocal strain gradient elasticity to capture size effects on the nonlinear secondary resonance of micro/nano-beams made of nanoporous biomaterials. Wang et al. [58] introduced a nonlocal strain gradient beam model for complex modal analysis for vibrational response of axially moving beams at nanoscale. Sahmani and Safaei [59] introduced a nonlocal strain gradient beam model for nonlinear free vibration response of 2D-FGM micro/nano-beams. Apuzzo et al. [60] examined the nonlinear bending behavior of FGM inflected nanobeams on the basis of the modified nonlocal strain gradient theory of elasticity. Hu et al. [61] anticipated the nonlocal strain gradient nonlinear vibrations of imperfect FGM sandwich micro/nano-beams. Sahmani et al. [62–64] put the nonlocal strain gradient elasticity to use for nonlinear free and forced vibrations of micro/nano-beams made of FGM or porous materials.
The main aim of the current work is to analyze the nonlinear primary resonance of a periodic soft excited 2D-FGM micro/nano-beam in the presence of the nonlocality and strain gradient size dependencies. For this end, the nonlocal strain gradient theory of elasticity is applied to the refined hyperbolic shear deformation beam theory to construct an efficient size-dependent beam model. The Hamilton's principle is put to use to derive the non-classical differential equations of motion. After that, a discretization scheme based numerical solution methodology via the generalized differential quadrature method (GDQM) together with the pseudo-arclength continuation technique is employed to solve the size-dependent nonlinear problem.

According to the previous investigations, each of the nonlocal elasticity theory and strain gradient elasticity theory has no capability to take size effects into consideration comprehensively. The nonlocal theory cannot take the higher-order stresses into account. Also, the strain gradient theory has the capability to consider only local higher order strain gradients. Motivated by this fact, Lim et al. [39] proposed a combination of these theories namely as nonlocal strain gradient elasticity theory which assess small scale effects more reasonably. Accordingly, the total nonlocal strain gradient stress tensor for a beamtype structure can be defined as below [39].
x * xx xx xx= (6a)

4. Numerical results and discussion
In this section, the size-dependent frequency response and amplitude response associated with the nonlinear forced oscillations of 2DFGM micro/nano-beams are presented corresponding to different
values of the nonlocal and strain gradient parameters as well as various longitudinal and lateral material property indexes. The two phases of the 2D-FGM are selected as silicon for the ceramic part with E GPa210c = , 0.35c = , Kg m2400 /c 3= , and aluminum for the metallic part with E GPa70 ,m = 0.24m = , Kg m2700 /m 3= . Also, in all of the preceding numerical results, the geometrical properties of the micro/nano-beam are assumed as b h nm20= = and L h20 .=
At first, in order to check the validity of the presented numerical results, the terms related to the strain gradient size dependency are ignored and the fundamental linear natural frequency of an isotropic nonlocal nanobeam with simply supported boundary conditions are obtained and compared with those given by Reddy [85] using an exact solution corresponding to various values of the nonlocal parameter as given in Table 1. An excellent agreement is found which confirms the validity as well as the accuracy of developed numerical solution methodology.
Figs. 3 and 4 illustrate the size-dependent frequency response of a harmonic excited 2D-FGM micro/nano-beam with different boundary conditions corresponding to various values of the nonlocal and strain gradient parameters, respectively. It can be observed that the nonlocality causes to increase the peak of the oscillation amplitude as well as the associated excitation frequency. However, the strain gradient size effect plays an opposite role and leads to reduce them. These observations may be related to this fact that the nonlocal size effect makes a reduction in the stiffness of a 2D-FGM micro/nano-beam which results in higher geometrical nonlinearity. On the other hand, the strain gradient size effect causes an increment in the stiffness of a 2D-FGM micro/nano-beam, so the associated nonlinear deformation decreases.
In Figs. 5 and 6, the size-dependent amplitude response of a harmonic excited 2D-FGM micro/nano-beam with different boundary conditions is shown corresponding to various values of the nonlocal and strain gradient parameters, respectively. It is demonstrated that the nonlocal size dependency makes a reduction in the oscillation amplitudes associated with both of the bifurcation points, but the strain gradient size effect causes to increase them. These patterns are more significant for the second bifurcation point and for the simply supported-simply supported (SS-SS) boundary conditions in comparison with the clamped-clamped (C-C) ones. Moreover, it is seen that the nonlocal and strain gradient size effects leads to, respectively, decrease and increase the value of the excitation frequency associated with the bifurcation points, but these patterns are more considerable for the first bifurcation point.
In Table 2, the nonlocal strain gradient natural frequencies of 2DFGM micro/nano-beams are given corresponding to different values of
the small scale parameter and various end supports. It is found that in the absence of the nonlocality, the increment in the natural frequency caused by the strain gradient size dependency is more than the
q q q q q q q q qG [ ] [ ] [ ] [ ] [ ] [ ] [ ] [ ] [ ]u nt u nt m u nt w nt w nt m w nt nt nt m nt1 1 2 1 1 1 1 2 1 1 1 1 2 1 1= × × × × × × × × ×
reduction in the value of the natural frequency caused by the nonlocal size effect in the absence of the strain gradient size dependency. This prediction becomes more significant by changing the boundary conditions from SS-SS ones to C-C ones.
Figs. 7 and 8 depict, respectively, the influence of the axial and lateral material property gradient indexes on the frequency response associated with the nonlinear primary resonance of 2D-FGM micro/ nano-beams. It is revealed that in the both cases, by moving from the
ceramic rich micro/nano-beam to the metal rich one, the peak of the oscillation amplitude and its associated excitation frequency increase. This anticipations are the same for SS-SS and C-C boundary conditions.
In Figs. 9 and 10, in order the influence of the axial and lateral property gradient indexes on the amplitude response associated with the nonlinear primary resonance of 2D-FGM micro/nano-beams is displayed. It can be seen that increasing the value of the axial or lateral material property gradient index leads to reduce the excitation amplitudes associated with the first and second bifurcation points, but this reduction is more prominent for the first one. Furthermore, an increment in the value of the axial or lateral material property gradient index, the oscillation amplitude at both of the bifurcation points decrease, but for the second one, the significance of this reduction is more than that of the first one.
Tabulated in Table 3 are the nonlocal strain gradient natural frequencies of 2D-FGM micro/nano-beams corresponding to various values of the axial and lateral material property gradient indexes and different boundary conditions. It is indicated that for lower values of 1 and 2, the reduction in the natural frequency caused by the lateral material property gradient index is more than that caused by the axial
material property gradient index. However, for higher values of 1 and 2, this pattern becomes vice versa. Also, it is observed that the type of the boundary conditions has no considerable effect on the significance of the influence of the axial and lateral material property gradient indexes on the vibrational response of 2D-FGM micro/nano-beams.
5. Conclusion
In this investigation, the size-dependent nonlinear resonant dynamics response of harmonic excited 2D-FGM micro/nano-beams was studied. Accordingly, the nonlocal strain gradient theory of elasticity together with the von-Karman geometrical nonlinearity was implemented into the refined hyperbolic shear deformation beam theory. The variational principle of Hamilton was put to use to derive the nonclassical governing differential equations of motion. Thereafter, a numerical solution methodology using GDQM in conjunction with the pseudo-arclength continuation technique was employed to solve the size-dependent nonlinear problem.
It was seen that the nonlocality causes to increase the peak of the oscillation amplitude as well as the associated excitation frequency.
However, the strain gradient size effect plays an opposite role and leads to reduce them. Additionally, it was revealed that the nonlocal size dependency makes a reduction in the oscillation amplitudes associated with both of the bifurcation points, but the strain gradient size effect causes to increase them. These patterns are more significant for the second bifurcation point and for SS-SS boundary conditions in comparison with the C-C ones. It was indicated that in the absence of the nonlocality, the increment in the natural frequency caused by the strain gradient size dependency is more than the reduction in the value of the natural frequency caused by the nonlocal size effect in the absence of the strain gradient size dependency.
It was observed, by moving from the ceramic rich micro/nano-beam to the metal rich one, the peak of the oscillation amplitude and its
associated excitation frequency increase. It was demonstrated that increasing the value of the axial or lateral material property gradient index leads to reduce the excitation amplitudes associated with the first and second bifurcation points, but this reduction is more prominent for the first one. Furthermore, an increment in the value of the axial or lateral material property gradient index, the oscillation amplitude at both of the bifurcation points decrease, but for the second one, the significance of this reduction is more than that of the first one. It was found that for lower values of 1 and 2, the reduction in the natural frequency caused by the lateral material property gradient index is more than that caused by the axial material property gradient index. However, for higher values of 1 and 2, this pattern becomes vice versa.

metadata.abstractText: With the aid of advanced design techniques, functionally graded materials as promising new materials can be fabricated into various micro/nano-structures to acquire stronger mechanical performance. In this work, the size-dependent nonlinear primary resonance of periodic soft excited micro/nano-beams made of bi-directional functionally graded materials (2D-FGMs) is studied. To accomplish this end, the nonlocal strain gradient theory of elasticity is utilized within the framework of the refined hyperbolic shear deformation beam theory to construct a size-dependent beam model. On the basis of the variational approach using the principle of Hamilton, the non-classical differential equations of motion are achieved. Thereafter, a discretization scheme based numerical solving process via generalized differential quadrature method (GDQM) together with the pseudo-arclength continuation technique, the nonlocal strain gradient frequency response and amplitude response associated with the nonlinear primary resonance of 2D-FGM micro/nano-beams with different boundary conditions are obtained. It is displayed that the nonlocal size dependency makes a reduction in the oscillation amplitudes associated with both of the bifurcation points, but the strain gradient size effect causes to increase them. These patterns are more significant for the second bifurcation point and for the simply supported-simply supported boundary conditions in comparison with the clamped-clamped ones. Also, it is observed that by increasing the value of both of the axial and lateral material property gradient indexes, the peak of the oscillation amplitude and its associated excitation frequency increase.
